rule.title: help/unknown_word.xml
rule.summary: Check the spelling of this word.

rule.title: help/spelling_flag.xml
rule.summary:
This word is not in the spelling dictionary. The dictionary consists of:

  • the Acrolinx IQ dictionary,
  • your terminology, and
  • several additional word lists.

If the word is spelled correctly, contact your linguistic administrator to have it added to the dictionary.

rule.title: help/use_this_that_these_those_with_noun.xml
rule.summary:
Use a corresponding noun after this, that, these and those. Readers may have difficulties to refer the pronouns (this, these, that, those) to their antecedents. For example:

  • "I made a cake."
  • "Wow! This smells good!"

The word This in "Wow! This smells good!" refers to the cake. The cake is the antecedent of this.

rule.title: help/a_an_distinction.xml
rule.summary:
General Guidelines

Pay attention to the sound that the word begins with, not necessarily the letter. Use a before a word that begins with a consonant sound. Use an before a word that begins with a vowel sound.

  • an interface module
  • an x-ray machine
  • a user interface
  • a new user

Variation

Acronyms

Acronyms can cause difficulty when deciding between a and an. Think about how you would say the acronym aloud. Do you pronounce each letter individually, or do you say it like a word?

  • an RSS news feed
  • an SEC ruling
  • a RAM module
  • a NATO conference

Some acronyms are commonly pronounced both ways. Consult the best practice guidelines of your company to decide which variant to use.

  • an FAQ forum
  • a FAQ forum (pronounced fak)
  • an SQL server
  • a SQL server (pronounced sequel)


Regional and stylistic variation

Some words are pronounced differently depending on region or style. These words, especially those beginning with h, can vary in the choice of a or an.

  • an herb
  • a herb
  • an historic occasion
  • a historic occasion

rule.title: help/use_standard_word_order.xml
rule.summary: Use the standard English word order. Do not end a sentence with a preposition or an adverb.

rule.title: help/avoid_duplicates.xml
rule.summary: Avoid duplicate words that make the meaning nonsensical. Such mistakes often result when a writer rewords a phrase while typing but does not recheck the entire sentence for clarity.

rule.title: help/use_preposition_with_ing_verb.xml
rule.summary: Prepositions (e.g. about, against, before, by, for, from, in, of, on, with) are generally followed by verb + -ing.

rule.title: help/avoid_modal_verbs.xml
rule.summary:
To improve readability and translatability, avoid using modal verbs in your content.

Modal verbs include the following:

  • may
  • might
  • shall
  • should
  • ought to

Modal verbs create ambiguity and reduce translatability and readability.

rule.title: help/keep_two_verb_parts_together.xml
rule.summary:
Keep both parts of a two-part verb together to increase the translation quality and the readability.

Two-part verbs are also called phrasal verbs. Phrasal verbs usually consist of a verb followed by a preposition or a particle

rule.title: help/avoid_verb_with_particle.xml
rule.summary: no phrasal verbs

rule.title: help/use_imperative.xml
rule.summary: Use the imperative whenever possible (especially in procedures).

rule.title: help/sentence_too_long.xml
rule.summary: This sentence is too long. Long sentences are difficult to read and to translate. Use short sentences instead.

rule.title: help/use_serial_comma.xml
rule.summary: According to The Chicago Manual of Style and Microsoft Manual of Style, items in a list are separated by commas. When a conjunction (for example, and, or) joins the last two elements in a list of three or more, a comma appears before the conjunction.

rule.title: help/unnecessary_space.xml
rule.summary: Delete the space before punctuation mark. Avoid placing a space after an opening bracket or before a closing bracket.

rule.title: help/avoid_embedded_sentences.xml
rule.summary: Do not use more than two clauses. Longer sentences are harder to understand than shorter sentences.

rule.title: help/use_sentence_case.xml
rule.summary: Use sentence case. The first word in the sentence begins with an uppercase letter, with all other letters and words in lowercase. Exceptions: proper nouns (e.g. Peter, Mary, Acrolinx), acronyms (HIV, AIDS, USB). Rewrite sentences that start with a case-sensitive lowercase word. For example, printf.

rule.title: help/missing_end_of_sentence_punctuation.xml
rule.summary: Probably it is a missing end of sentence. Sentences which start with a lowercase are not considered to be potential sentence which would need an end-of-sentence punctuation.

rule.title: help/missing_word.xml
rule.summary:
There seems to be a missing word here.

The reason can be:

  • missing a subject
  • missing a verb
  • missing a preposition
  • missing a relative pronoun

rule.title: help/wrong_verb_form.xml
rule.summary:
The verb form is incorrect. Make sure that there is not a mismatch of verb tenses.

can, cannot, should, have to + infinitive verb

have, be + past participle

rule.title: help/missing_space.xml
rule.summary: Insert a space after the punctuation.

rule.title: help/noun_adjective_confusion.xml
rule.summary:
Follow these general guidelines for determining whether two words should be written separately or hyphenated:

  • Nouns are generally written separately.
  • Adjectives are generally hyphenated.

Example:

  • back office is a noun: The back office remains hidden from customers.Important operations take place in the back office.
  • back-office is an adjective: Back-office operations are extremely important.Important operations are often back-office.

rule.title: help/np_number_agreement.xml
rule.summary:
Make sure that the noun agrees with the word before it. Use singular nouns with singular articles and numbers. Use plural nouns with plural articles and numbers.

Use the following with singular nouns:

  • a
  • an
  • this
  • one

Use the following with plural nouns:

  • these
  • those
  • several
  • all numbers except one

rule.title: help/use_article.xml
rule.summary: Use articles in noun phrases whenever possible.

rule.title: help/use_gender_neutral_words.xml
rule.summary:
Do not use gender-specific words such as he, she, s/he, and he/she.
Note: Terms entered in the Acrolinx IQ are treated as exceptions to this rule.

rule.title: help/wrong_sequence_of_words.xml
rule.summary: The sequence of words seems to be incorrect. A word might be missing, one of the marked words might be misspelled or unnecessary, or the word order might be incorrect.

rule.title: help/its_it_is_confusion.xml
rule.summary:
The words it's and its can cause confusion.

With nouns, 's expresses belonging.

  • The IT staff constantly review the system and the system's settings.
  • The representative introduced the company and the company's CEO.

It is an exception to this rule and takes only s without an apostrophe to express belonging.

Use it's as a contraction of it is.

  • It's important that we finish on time.
  • We will know if it's working.

Use its to mean belonging to it.

  • The IT staff constantly review the system and its settings.
  • The representative introduced the company and its CEO.

rule.title: help/avoid_contractions.xml
rule.summary:
Avoid contractions in technical writing. They are colloquial abbreviations which are common in informal writing. Some contractions are ambigious. For examples, they'd.
Note: Terms entered in the Acrolinx IQ are treated as exceptions to this rule.

Avoid positive contractions, such as:

  • I'm
  • I'll
  • I'd
  • I've
  • You're

rule.title: help/there_their_confusion.xml
rule.summary:
The words there, their, and they're can cause confusion.

Use there to refer to a location.

  • The company has two branch offices there.
  • We have started a new line of products over there.

Use their to mean belonging to them.

  • The company has contacts at their headquarters.
  • We have started to make inroads in their market.

Use they're as a contraction of they are.

  • The customers have indicated that they're ready for something new.
  • They're impressed by that presentation.

rule.title: help/internet_and_web_capitalization.xml
rule.summary:
Do not capitalize web when it is used as an adjective. Capitalize World Wide Web and the Web. Do not capitalize internet when it is used as an adjective, but capitalize Internet as a noun (that is, if you refer to the Internet).
Note: Terms entered in the Acrolinx IQ are treated as exceptions to this rule.

rule.title: help/avoid_colloquialism_and_metaphorical_language.xml
rule.summary: Colloquialisms are informal expressions that are difficult to translate automatically, as well as metaphorical language.

rule.title: help/avoid_future_tense_with_suggestions.xml
rule.summary:
Use the present tense wherever you can. Avoid the future tense and future passive tenses.

Use the future tense to indicate a definite future event.

rule.title: help/do_not_use_complex_sentences.xml
rule.summary: This sentence has several complex constructions (nested sentences, passive, coordination, noun clusters, etc.) and is difficult to understand.

rule.title: help/use_relative_pronoun.xml
rule.summary: Do not omit relative pronouns such as "that" and "which." The rule does not flag if adding the relative pronouns would create too many embedded clauses and an overly complex sentence.

rule.title: help/repeat_subject.xml
rule.summary: Repeat the subject.

rule.title: help/use_comma_after_introductory_phrase.xml
rule.summary:
Do not overuse commas. Break long sentences with commas into shorter sentences to make the sentences clearer.

However, you can use commas after introductory (infinitive) phrases or adverbial clauses. An introductory phrase usually starts with a preposition.

rule.title: help/avoid_possessives.xml
rule.summary:
Avoid the use of possessive in technical documentation.

In possessives, the placement of the apostrophe depends on whether the noun that shows possession is singular or plural. Generally, if the noun is singular, the apostrophe goes before the s. The witch's broom. If the noun is plural, the apostrophe goes after the s: The witches' brooms. However, if the word is pluralized without an s, the apostrophe comes before the s: He entered the men's room with an armload of children's clothing. If you create a possessive with a phrase like 'of the witches', you will use no apostrophe: The brooms of the witches.


Note: Terms entered in the Acrolinx IQ are treated as exceptions to this rule.

rule.title: help/avoid_needless_word.xml
rule.summary:
Avoid unnecessary words that do not add meaning to your text. In most cases, you can leave out the word without changing the meaning. For example, avoid the following adverbs:

  • absolutely
  • actually
  • approximately
  • basically
  • certainly
  • completely
  • definitively
  • essentially
  • extremely
  • generally
  • hugely
  • just
  • mainly
  • minimally
  • obviously
  • particularly
  • perhaps
  • please
  • pretty
  • quite
  • significantly
  • simply
  • somewhat
  • strongly
  • very
  • virtually


Note: Terms entered in the Acrolinx IQ are treated as exceptions to this rule.

rule.title: help/subject_verb_agreement.xml
rule.summary:
General Guidelines

The subject of the sentence must agree with the verb in number. In other words, if the noun or pronoun which does something is plural, then the verb must be plural as well. Likewise if the noun or pronoun is singular, the verb must be singular too.

  • The interface module is ready.
  • The interface modules are ready.


Special Cases

Pronouns: words like anyone or no one

Some pronouns always take a singular verb, even when they seem to have a plural meaning, for example anyone, anybody, everyone, everybody, someone, somebody, no one, nobody, each, neither, and either.

  • Everyone is ready to begin.
  • Nobody knows the correct procedure.
  • Each of the computers needs repair.
  • Do you have a preference? Either is acceptable.

There and here

In sentences starting with there or here, the subject of the sentence comes after the verb.

  • Here are two possible explanations for the slow download.
  • Is there a way to deactivate the firewall?

Collective nouns

Some words look like they have a plural form but are in fact singular, for example news or measles. On the other hand, some singular words ending in -s do take a plural verb, such as assets, earnings, or thanks. Consult a dictionary if you are unsure whether a word is singular or plural.

  • The news from abroad is positive.
  • The earnings from last quarter are encouraging.

Some collective nouns can be singular or plural, depending on how you mean them. If you are referring to a group as a unit, use a singular verb. If you are referring to the individuals within a group, use a plural verb.

  • In terms of licenses, a dozen is probably enough for your company.
  • In terms of users, a dozen have already registered.

rule.title: help/to_too_confusion.xml
rule.summary:
The words too and to can cause confusion.

Use too only when you mean also or in excess.

  • When the antivirus sweeps your hard drive, it will sweep peripheral devices too.
  • If you put too much oil in the tank, it will overflow.

Use to for all other senses of the word.

  • Press here to start.
  • Clicking here will lead you to the home page.

rule.title: help/avoid_run_on_sentence.xml
rule.summary: A run-on sentence occurs when there are two sentences (independent clauses) in one sentence without the proper punctuation to set them apart. Two independent clauses in one sentence need to be separated by either a semicolon or a comma plus coordinating conjunction (and, or, but, so, yet). Alternatively, the two independent clauses can be broken out into two separate sentences.

rule.title: help/use_end_of_sentence_punctuation.xml
rule.summary: Use a semicolon between independent clauses that are connected by a conjunctive adverb or a transitional phrase. Conjunctive adverbs include "also", "besides", "consequently", "conversely", "finally", "however", "instead", "likewise", "next", "otherwise", "similarly", "specifically", "still", "subsequently", "then", and "therefore". Transitional phrases include "at the same time", "for example", "in addition", and "on the contrary".

rule.title: help/possibly_end_of_sentence.xml
rule.summary: Make sure that you include a noun after the phrases the following and the previous.

rule.title: help/missing_subject_with_suggest.xml
rule.summary: Make sure that the sentence contains a subject.

rule.title: help/avoid_noun_cluster.xml
rule.summary:
In English, one or more nouns can modify a different noun. In technical language, phrases frequently have more than one noun. These groups of nouns are noun clusters, and if they are too lengthy, they can confuse the reader. Shorter noun clusters are easier to understand. The primary noun and the other nouns that modify it are closer together. In longer noun clusters, some nouns refer to nouns that are not the primary noun (which is usually the last noun).
NOTE: This rule does not trigger for capitalized words, abbreviations, or acronyms.

rule.title: help/duplicate_punctuation_mark.xml
rule.summary: Avoid duplicate punctuation marks.

rule.title: help/incorrect_extra_comma.xml
rule.summary: Commas in English are generally not used before that, in order to, so that, if, or time and place words such as when and where.
